Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mobile Farming Families of Southern Appalachia and the Mexican Bajio

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
North American agricultural livelihoods have gone through significant transitions since the late twentieth century. Changes include the restructuring of food systems so that local farming economies are increasingly tied to global networks and processes. One somewhat surprising response on the part of local food producers has been the rise of binational family-based farming enterprises, which, despite being small to midscale ventures, successfully coordinate across state lines to facilitate vertically integrated operations, mitigate inequities, and access produce markets. The research supported by this award will investigate how this occurs: how do local family fruit and vegetable producers utilize global networks, coordinate transregional projects, and contribute to food system circulations? And what role do traditional modes of organizing family farms, such as kinship networks, play in contemporary farming operations? The research will be carried out by University of Kentucky doctoral student Mary Elizabeth W. Schmid, with direction from anthropologist Dr. Ann E. Kingsolver, in the western North Carolina region of southern Appalachia, with comparative research in other southeastern U.S. states and Mexico.

Schmid will document family and enterprise histories, provisioning strategies, forms of relatedness, cultural practices, and decision-making processes to determine how members draw on family and non-family relations to enable strategic production, distribution, and marketing coordination across time and space. Her mixed methods approach will include archival research, participant observation, interviewing, social network analysis, ethnographic mapping, and qualitative analysis of textual data. She will map family and enterprise networks, temporal cycles, transnational kinship circuit flows, and the social organization of fruit and vegetable production and marketing. Findings from this research will contribute to understanding the functioning of small to midscale fruit and vegetable production enterprises in the contemporary economy and the social and economic effects of agricultural policies intended to regulate this sector.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project aimed to investigate the ways in which binational (Mexican American) families organize their small- to mid-scale farming enterprises, engage in global networks as food producers and contribute to rural food economies in the southeastern U.S. Farming families throughout North America have experienced significant transitions over the last four decades. The restructuring of food systems mean that local farming economies are increasingly tied to global networks, market prices and processes. The research for this project was based in western North and South Carolina, mainly, with additional fieldwork conducted in multiple sites throughout the southeastern U.S. and central Mexico where farming families’ kin reside and farm. Methods included archival research, participant observation, interviewing, farmers’ market vender questionnaires, food system mapping, time-based enterprise mapping, and qualitative analysis of textual data. The researcher documented family and enterprise histories, provisioning strategies, forms of relatedness, cultural practices, and decision-making processes to determine how members draw on family and non-family relations to enable strategic production, distribution, and marketing coordination across time and space. Local agricultural offices in each state where research was conducted were consulted to ensure that data collection would not be redundant.  

The research project produced several significant findings that contribute to the broader public and intellectual advancement within social scientific fields. First, it confirmed that Mexican American families are working together to organize and operate fresh-market fruit and vegetable farming and marketing enterprises in the southeastern U.S. as entrepreneurs. Though members of these kin groups work for many kinds of enterprises within the regional food system, they also collaborate as owner-operators of small- to mid-scale conventional fruit and vegetable farming enterprises. This finding corroborates the recent trend found by other studies that more minority groups are becoming farmers in the U.S. Second, Mexican American family-based farming enterprises are critical contributors to local food economies in several sites throughout the southeastern U.S. These enterprises contribute by providing the critical network linkages between industry groups at various stages of the supply chain, especially in the case of tomatoes and warm season vegetable production and distribution. Temporal skills in these family enterprises are key to their organizing marketing at the scale and complexity required. A third finding was that these enterprises are mobile in that they work with large-scale enterprises at various sites on seasonal commodity circuits. These family-based enterprises work with corporate-level enterprises to arrange multi-scalar coordination at the production stage, which is critical to the function of the fresh-market portion of the food system and economy in the region. These industry actors connect people beyond ethnic networks.

The findings of this study contribute to anthropological and rural economic development knowledge in five ways. First, they reveal often-overlooked contributions to local and regional food economies by multi-sited contributions by participants like members of these binational Mexican American families. They collaborate across state lines to create efficiencies and fill the knowledge and skill gaps that otherwise left unfilled could cause a breakdown in fresh-market vegetable supply chains in the U.S. Second, the results show that members of these farming families act as innovative entrepreneurs beyond the farm field in places like farmers’ markets and as transporters for other small- to mid-scale farming enterprises, helping to make the transition from cash crops like tobacco to fresh fruit and vegetable crops like tomatoes possible in the region. They combine ethnic and industry networks to facilitate business for operations beyond the ones they and their kin members own. Thirdly, the results of this project help us better understand the importance of kin relations to modern political economies and particular kinds of time-sensitive industries, like fresh-market produce. Kin-based collective practices provide examples for other cooperative agricultural activities that could inform agricultural cooperative extension agency programming, for example, especially in coordinating vertical integration in fresh fruit and vegetable production, which is a challenging area of production for small producers to manage as individuals. Fourthly, these kin-based entrepreneurs inform our understanding of the diverse social and economic effects of agricultural policies and programming intended to regulate fresh-market fruit and vegetable production enterprises in the contemporary southeastern U.S. economy. Fifthly, the findings expand knowledge of the ways that participants in local and regional food economies are much more diverse than what is usually represented – women, for example, may be involved as bookkeepers or marketers in farming enterprises but may not be recognized as “farmers.” One of the broader impacts of this study was helping to organize agricultural bookkeeping classes for Spanish-speakers in North Carolina.
